questions.question: Which of the following best describes the drainage pathway of the sinus that is marked with an arrow in the image below?

A 45-year-old patient complains of difficulty breathing through their nose. He also reports complaints of smell perception. The otolaryngologist decides to perform both the University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) and rhinomanometry. Which of the following statements regarding these tests is INCORRECT?

options.A: The UPSIT helps to understand if the patient's ability to perceive smell is good or bad.
options.B: Rhinomanometry is a subjective function test to assess nasal airflow.
options.C: In the UPSIT, the patient is given scratch cards of odorous stimuli and asked to write down the smell.
options.D: Rhinomanometry results can be used to check for improvement after nasal surgery.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rhinomanometry is a subjective function test to assess nasal airflow. and resistance. It involves measuring the pressure and airflow within the nasal cavity, providing valuable insights into nasal function. By quantifying nasal airflow parameters, such as resistance and volume, rhinomanometry aids in the evaluation of various nasal conditions, including nasal obstruction, allergic rhinitis, septal deviations and to assess improved nasal function after surgery. (Option D ruled out) UPSIT Test is University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test: It is a subjective test to assess smell perception. (Option A ruled out) Patients are given scratch cards of odorous stimuli to identify. (Option C ruled out) It is used to diagnose olfactory dysfunction associated with certain diseases. Tests done to assess nasal airflow: Subjective Tests: Nasal Airflow Questionnaire Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Objective Tests: Rhinomanometry Acoustic Rhinometry Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF) Tests done for smell perception: University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) Sniffin' Sticks Test Odor Threshold Test Olfactory Event-Related Potentials (OERP) Reference: Rhinomanometry - PMC Updated Percentiles for the University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the airflow dynamics during respiration through the nose is INCORRECT?

options.A: Mouth breathing is not present in newborns
options.B: Very little air passes through olfactory region of nose
options.C: Maximum airflow during quiet respiration occurs through inferior turbinate
options.D: Friction during expiration causes the air to form eddies at the nasal valve , ventilating the sinuses.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Maximum airflow during quiet respiration occurs through inferior turbinate turbinate. The nose is the natural and instinctive pathway for breathing, especially crucial for newborns. Mouth breathing is learned with age . (Option A ruled out) Inspiratory and expiratory airflows follow different patterns, with expiration being more complex and involving eddy current formation causing ventilation of sinuses . (Option D ruled out) The turbinates play a significant role in regulating airflow through swelling and shrinkage. The nasal cycle involves alternating congestion and decongestion of nasal chambers, regulating airflow. Each cycle lasts between 1.5-4 hours. The nose is multifunctional, allowing for simultaneous breathing and eating, as well as playing a crucial role in olfaction and air conditioning. Very little air passes through the inferior meatus or olfactory region of the nose. (Option B ruled out) The maximum airflow during quiet respiration occurs through middle turbinate in a parabolic pattern. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat Dhingra 8th Edition Page 162

questions.question: A junior resident is studying the anatomy of the medial wall of the orbit. Which of the following statements about this structure is INCORRECT? cell. wall of the orbit.

options.A: The medial walls of both orbits run parallel to each other and form the lateral walls of ethmoid air
options.B: The medial wall is formed by parts of the sphenoid, ethmoid, lacrimal, and maxillary bones.
options.C: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal foramina are located at the junction of the roof and the lateral
options.D: The optic canal is situated at the posterior junction of the medial wall and the roof of the orbit.

questions.explanation: roof and the lateral wall of the orbit. Correct Answer: C) The anterior and posterior ethmoidal foramina are located at the junction of the roof and the lateral wall of the orbit. Explanation: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal foramina are located at the junction of the roof and the medial wall of the orbit, not the lateral wall. Features of Medial Wall of Orbit Composition Formed by parts of the sphenoid bone, orbital surface of the ethmoid bone, lacrimal bone, and frontal process of the maxilla. Fig: Composition of Medial Wall of Orbit Orientation Runs parallel to the contralateral medial wall; forms lateral wall of nasal cavity Ethmoidal Air Cells Air-filled spaces in the ethmoid bone portion of the medial wall Foramina Anterior Ethmoidal Foramen Posterior Ethmoidal Foramen Optic canal The 6-12-24 rule: To locate important structures on the medial wall of the orbit, measured from the anterior lacrimal crest: Anterior Ethmoid Foramen: 24 mm from the anterior lacrimal crest. Posterior Ethmoid Foramen: 12 mm behind the anterior ethmoid foramen Optic Canal: 6 mm behind the posterior ethmoid foramen Reference: Radiopedia Pubmed IMAIOS

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the venous drainage of the nose is FALSE? ophthalmic vein. supratrochlear and supraorbital veins. venous connection.

options.A: The venous networks parallel the arterial supply in their distribution.
options.B: The fronto-median area drains to the facial vein, while the orbito-palpebral area drains to the
options.C: The facial vein originates as the angular vein, which is formed by the confluence of the
options.D: Infections in the upper lip and nose can potentially spread to the cavernous sinus due to a valveless

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The venous networks parallel the arterial supply in their distribution. arteriovenous units. Venous drainage of nose has following characteristics: The venous networks do not parallel the arterial supply but correspond to territories termed arteriovenous units. Different areas of the face drain to different veins (fronto-median to facial vein, orbito-palpebral to ophthalmic vein). (Option B) The facial vein originates as the angular vein, which is formed by the supratrochlear and supraorbital veins. (Option C) The upper lip and nose are considered a "danger area" due to the potential for retrograde infection spread to the cavernous sinus. (Option D) The venous system connecting the facial area to the cavernous sinus is valveless, allowing for potential bidirectional flow. Fig: Dangerous area of face

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the lining membrane of the internal nose is INCORRECT?

options.A: The vestibule is lined by skin containing hair, hair follicles, and sebaceous glands.
options.B: The olfactory region covers the lower two-thirds of the nasal cavity.
options.C: The respiratory region's mucous membrane is thickest over nasal conchae.
options.D: The olfactory region's membrane is paler in color compared to other regions.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The olfactory region covers the lower two-thirds of the nasal cavity. septum, and the roof of the nasal cavity. The respiratory region covers the lower two-thirds of the nasal cavity. Region Location Lining Key Feature Vestibule (Option A) Entrance of the nose Skin containing hair, hair follicles, and sebaceous glands Epithelium- Stratified squamous epithelium Acts as initial filter for air entering the nose Olfactory Region Upper one-third of lateral wall, corresponding part of nasal septum, and roof of nasal cavity Olfactory epithelium Specialized for detecting odors, membrane is paler in color (Option D) Respiratory Region Lower two-thirds of the nasal cavity Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells Variable thickness (thickest over nasal conchae) (Option C) , highly vascular, contains erectile tissue Fig: Linings of Nose Reference: Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat 8th Edition Page 160

questions.question: Which type of sphenoid sinus pneumatization is contraindicated in endoscopic transsphenoidal surgery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Conchal Explanation: Conchal Pneumatization involves minimal air space and dense trabecular bone, making surgical access to the sella tursica extremely difficult. The pneumatization of the sphenoid sinus refers to the extent to which air cells develop within the sphenoid bone, creating the hollow spaces of the sinus. This pattern can vary significantly among individuals, and it is categorized into three main types: Sellar Pneumatization - air cells extend posteriorly beyond the sella turcica . This type results in a well-developed sphenoid sinus. Most common(82%) It is ideal for this surgery because the sinus is well pneumatized Presellar Pneumatization - reaches up to the anterior wall of the sella but does not extend beyond it. This creates a smaller sinus compared to the sellar type. Sellar and Presellar Pneumatization provide adequate access for surgery. (Option A and B) Conchal Pneumatization - shallow bowl with minimal sphenoid pneumatization and trabecular bone between the sinus and sella. Lateral Pneumatization - extending into the pterygoid processes, resulting in the formation of a lateral sphenoid recess. While complex, is not a contraindication but may require additional surgical expertise. Post-sellar Pneumatization is a variant with pneumatization extending beyond the sella , which is generally acceptable for surgery, though it may carry additional risks depending on surrounding anatomy. Fig: Pneumatization types of the sphenoid sinus. A – conchal, B - pre-sellar, C – sellar. D - post-sellar.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male complains of deep-seated headaches and visual disturbances. Imaging reveals a sphenoid sinus mucocele compressing adjacent structures. Which of the following is most likely to be compressed by this mucocele?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Optic nerve Explanation: The sphenoid sinus is located in close proximity to several important neurovascular structures, including the optic nerve , which runs along the superior aspect of the sinus. Compression of the optic nerve can lead to visual disturbances. The sphenoid sinuses are the deepest of the paranasal sinuses, located within the body of the sphenoid bone. They are separated by a septum, often asymmetrical, and this septum may even be absent in about 1% of individuals. Features: Ostium: Located on the anterior medial wall Drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, medial to the superior turbinate Classification based on pneumatization: Conchal: Minimal or no pneumatization Presellar: Pneumatization anterior to the sella turcica Sellar: Pneumatization extends below the sella turcica Postsellar: Extensive pneumatization beyond the sella turcica Anatomical Relations: Lateral Wall : The optic nerve and internal carotid artery are prominent structures that indent the superolateral wall of the sphenoid sinus. The opticocarotid recess lies between the optic nerve and

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT true regarding the ethmoid air cells?

options.A: The anterior ethmoid air cells drain into the middle meatus.
options.B: They are the last of the paranasal sinuses to fully develop.
options.C: They are closely related to the orbit.
options.D: The posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) They are the last of the paranasal sinuses to fully develop. Sinus Appearance Full Development Maxillary Present at birth 15-18 years Ethmoid Present at birth 12-14 years Sphenoid 3-5 years 12-15 years Frontal 3-4 years 18-20 years Explanation Ethmoidal Sinus is found within the ethmoid bone and arises from the pneumatization (air cell formation) of the ethmoid bone. Ethmoid air cells are not fully developed at birth; they develop progressively after birth and continue growing until adolescence and are the first among the paranasal sinuses to fully develop. Air Cells: Divided into anterior and posterior groups. Up to 2-18 air cells may form. The largest anterior air cell is the ethmoid bulla . Drainage: Anterior air cells drain into the middle meatus. (Option A) Posterior air cells drain into the superior meatus. (Option D) Extra-Ethmoidal Pneumatizations Supraorbital Cell: Extends into the orbit bone. Haller Cell: Located at the roof of the maxillary sinus. Frontoethmoidal Cell: Found in the floor of the frontal sinus. Onodi Cell: Positioned superolateral to the sphenoid sinus, and may be closely related to the optic nerve and internal carotid artery. Anatomical Relations: Laterally: Separated from the orbit by the lamina papyracea. (Option C) Medially: Adjacent to the cribriform plate. Posterior boundary: Formed by the sphenoid sinus. Fig: Anatomical Relations of Ethmoid sinus

questions.question: All the following are paired cartilage forming the external nose anatomy except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Septal cartilage Explanation: The nasal septum/ septal cartilage present on the dorsum supporting the cartilaginous pyramid is the only unpaired cartilage. External nose anatomy It is pyramidal with its root up and the base directed downwards. The nasal pyramid consists of an osteocartilaginous framework covered by muscles and skin. The upper one-third of the external nose is bony while the lower two-thirds are cartilaginous. Paired cartilages: Upper lateral cartilage, lower lateral cartilage, sesamoid cartilage (Option B, C, D) Fig: Anatomy of External Nose Bony part: The bony part consists of two nasal bones which meet in the midline and rest on the upper part of the nasal process of the frontal bones and are also held between the frontal processes of the maxillae. Paired bones: nasal bone and Ascending process of the maxilla Unpaired bones: Frontal bone Cartilaginous part: It consists of: 1. Upper lateral cartilages: Extend from nasal bones to alar cartilage Fuse with each other and septal cartilage anteriorly The lower free edge of upper lateral cartilage is seen intranasally as limen vestibule, nasal valve, or limen nasi on each side. 2. Lower lateral cartilages (alar cartilages): Each alar cartilage is U-shaped. It has a lateral crus which forms the ala and a medial crus which runs in the columella. The lateral crus overlaps the lower edge of the upper lateral cartilage on each side. 3. Lesser alar (or sesamoid) cartilages: They are two or more in number. They lie above and lateral to the alar cartilage. 4. Septal cartilage: Also called quadrangular or quadrilateral cartilage has four borders. It supports the dorsum of the cartilaginous part of the nose. In septal abscess or after excessive removal of septal cartilage as in submucosal resection (SMR) operation, support of nasal dorsum is lost, and a supra tip depression results.

questions.question: Which structure lies posterior to the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pterygopalatine fossa Explanation: The pterygopalatine fossa is located immediately posterior to the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. This space contains vital neurovascular structures, including: Maxillary nerve (V2) Branches of the maxillary artery , such as the sphenopalatine artery The pterygopalatine ganglion The maxillary sinus or the Antrum of Highmore , is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, occupying the body of the maxilla. Shape - Pyramidal Size - 15mL Base - toward the lateral wall of the nose Apex - extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone Relations: Anterior wall: Formed by the facial surface of the maxilla. Posterior wall: Anterior surface of pterygopalatine fossa. Medial wall: Thin and membranous in some areas, this wall borders the middle and inferior meatuses and separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity. Roof: Formed by the floor of the orbit Floor: Located approximately 1 cm below the floor of the nasal cavity, it is formed by the alveolar and palatine processes of the maxilla. Closely related to the roots of the second premolar and first molar teeth. Cavities in these teeth are associated with oro-antral fistula. Fig: Anatomy of Maxillary sinus Arterial supply: Branches of the maxillary artery, specifically the infraorbital artery, greater palatine artery, and the posterior superior alveolar artery. Fig: Blood supply of Maxillary sinus Venous drainage: Pterygoid venous plexus and the facial vein. Lymphatic drainage: Submandibular lymph nodes. Nerve supply: Infraorbital nerve, greater palatine nerve, and the posterior superior alveolar nerve, which are branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2). Nasolacrimal duct (Option A) : Runs anteriorly and medially, draining tears into the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity. Optic nerve (Option B) : Associated with the sphenoid sinus, located superiorly in the orbit, not near the maxillary sinus's posterior wall. Inferior rectus muscle (Option D) : Lies superior to the maxillary sinus, closely related to the orbital floor but unrelated to the posterior wall of the sinus.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a part of the middle meatus of the nose?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Nasolacrimal duct opening Explanation: The nasolacrimal duct guarded at its terminal end by a mucosal valve called Hasner’s valve opens into the inferior meatus , not the middle meatus. Components of the Middle Meatus of the Nose: Uncinate Process: (Option A) Hook-like structure running from anterosuperior to posteroinferior. Forms a gap with the bulla ethmoidalis called the hiatus semilunaris inferior . Divides the lower middle meatus into anterior and posterior fontanelles (membranous areas). Infundibulum: Bounded medially by the uncinate process and laterally by the lamina papyracea . Contains the natural ostium of the maxillary sinus in its lower part. Bulla Ethmoidalis: (Option B) Ethmoidal cell located behind the uncinate process, forming the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris. May be pneumatized or a solid prominence. Hiatus Semilunaris: Inferior : The gap between the uncinate process and bulla. Superior : The cleft between the bulla and skull base. Ostiomeatal Unit (Complex): (Option C) Key area where the ostia of the frontal, ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses drain into the middle meatus. Common drainage pathway for the anterior group of sinuses . Fig: Components of the Middle Meatus of the Nose Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra 8th Edition Page 156- 159

questions.question: Match the following: 1. Middle Meatus a) Sphenoid sinus 2. Superior Meatus b) Frontal sinus 3. Sphenoethmoidal Recess c) Posterior Ethmoid sinus
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a Explanation: MEATUS DRAINAGE OF SINUS Middle Meatus Ostiomeatal Unit or Complex of frontal, anterior ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses drain. Common drainage pathway of anterior group of sinuses. Superior Meatus Posterior Ethmoid sinus drains. Sphenoethmoidal Recess Sphenoid sinus drains. Inferior Meatus The nasolacrimal duct opens here. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra 8th Edition Page. 159

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the lateral nasal wall is correct?

options.A: The lateral nasal wall has turbinates: inferior, middle, superior, and supreme.
options.B: Spaces below the turbinates are called sinuses.
options.C: The turbinates include inferior, middle, superior, and lateral.
options.D: Spaces below the turbinates are meatuses: superior, middle, and supreme.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The lateral nasal wall has turbinates: inferior, middle, superior, and supreme. supreme. Lateral Nasal Wall It has 3 bony projections known as turbinate or conchae . (Option C ruled out) Inferior turbinate Middle turbinate Superior turbinate. Sometimes, supreme turbinate is present in few. Spaces below the turbinates are known as Meatus . (Option B & D ruled out) Inferior meatus Middle meatus Superior meatus. Fig: Lateral Nasal Wall Anatomy Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra 8th Edition Pg. 156- 159

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the medial wall of the nose is FALSE? sphenopalatine, and infraorbital arteries.

options.A: The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the internal carotid system.
options.B: The sphenopalatine artery is a branch of the maxillary artery from the external carotid system.
options.C: Kiesselbach’s plexus is formed by the anastomosis of the anterior & posterior ethmoidal,
options.D: The columellar septum is formed by the medial crura of the alar cartilages.

questions.explanation: ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, and infraorbital arteries. Correct Answer: C) Kiesselbach’s plexus is formed by the anastomosis of the anterior & posterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, and infraorbital arteries. Explanation: Kiesselbach's plexus is formed by the anastomosis of the anterior ethmoidal artery, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery, and septal branch of the superior labial artery. The posterior ethmoidal and infraorbital artery are not involved in forming this plexus . Nasal septum forms the medial wall. Medial wall of nose (Nasal septum) Components of Nasal septum: Columellar Septum Formed by the columella containing medial crura of alar cartilages. (Option D) United by fibrous tissue and covered by skin. Membranous Septum Composed of a double layer of skin without bony or cartilaginous support. Located between the columella and the caudal border of the septal cartilage. Freely movable from side to side. Septum Proper Consists of osteocartilaginous framework covered with nasal mucous membrane. Principal parts: Perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone. Vomer bone. Septal (quadrilateral) cartilage between the ethmoid and vomer. Minor contributions from surrounding bones: nasal bones, frontal bone, sphenoid, palatine bones, maxilla, and anterior nasal spine. Fig: Septum Proper Nasal Septum Blood Supply: Internal Carotid System Anterior Ethmoidal Artery: (Option A) A branch of the ophthalmic artery. Posterior Ethmoidal Artery: A branch of the ophthalmic artery. External Carotid System Sphenopalatine Artery (SPA): (Option B) A branch of the maxillary artery. Gives off nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches. Septal Branch of Greater Palatine Artery: A branch of the maxillary artery. Septal Branch of Superior Labial Artery: A branch of the facial artery. Little’s Area (Kiesselbach’s Plexus) Located at Anterior-inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. Formed by the anastomosis of: (Option C) Anterior ethmoidal artery Sphenopalatine artery Greater palatine artery Septal branch of the superior labial artery Commonest site for nosebleeds (epistaxis). Most common cause: Trauma/Nose Picking Most common cause in adults: Hypertension Site where "bleeding polypus" (haemangioma) of the nasal septum can originate. Venous plexus that is present at the posteroinferior portion of the septum is known as Woodruff's plexus . Fig: Blood supply of Nasal Septum

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the nose are true? The anterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the nasal bones. The floor of the nose is formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. The posterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the body of the sphenoid bone. The anterior three-fourths of the floor of the nose is formed by the palatine process of the maxilla. The posterior one-fourth of the floor of the nose is formed by the horizontal part of the sphenoid bone.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4 Explanation: Each nasal cavity features a lateral wall, a medial wall, a roof, and a floor. Roof of the nose Floor of the nose Anterior Sloping Part : Formed by the nasal bones. (Statement 1) Posterior Sloping Part : Formed by the body of the sphenoid bone. (Statement 3) Middle Horizontal Part : Formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (passage of olfactory nerves into the nasal cavity). (Statement 2) Anterior Three-Fourths : Formed by the palatine process of the maxilla. (Statement 4) Posterior One-Fourth : Formed by the horizontal part of the palatine bone. (Statement 5)

questions.question: What is the primary function of the nasal valve in the nasal respiratory system?

options.A: To provide resonance to the voice
options.B: Regulating airflow resistance and airflow dynamics
options.C: Modulating the temperature and humidity of inspired air

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Regulating airflow resistance and airflow dynamics Explanation: The nasal valve is the narrowest area in the nose and plays an important part in regulating the flow of air into the nose. Physiologically, it provides resistance to the flow of air and thus helps in filtration, warming, and humidification of air. The anterior and inferior part of the nasal cavity is called the vestibule. Lined by stratified squamous epithelium and contains sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and the hair called vibrissae. It has 2 valves. Its upper limit on the lateral wall is marked by limen nasi (also called nasal valve). Nasal valve: Boundaries: Medially by the septum, superiorly by the lower border of the upper lateral cartilage, and inferiorly by the head of the inferior turbinate. The upper lateral cartilage meets the nasal septum in the midline forming an angle of 10-15°. During hump removal and medialization of the nasal dorsum in rhinoplasty, the function of this valve may get disturbed leading to nasal obstruction. Nasal valve area: It is the cross-sectional area at the level of the lower border of upper lateral cartilage, the corresponding part of the caudal septum, and the head of the inferior turbinate and measures nearly 55-73 mm. External nasal valve : Is the cross-sectional area of the nasal vestibule, i.e. the opening of the nasal vestibule. It is made of alar cartilage and fibro-fatty tissue and is controlled by nasal muscles. Boundaries: Medially by columella, laterally by ala of nose, and inferiorly by the skin of the floor To provide resonance to the voice is the functions of paranasal sinuses(Option A) Modulating the temperature and humidity of inspired air is a function that occurs in the nasal cavity, but it's not the primary function of the nasal valve specifically. (Option C) Sensing and processing olfactory stimuli are sensed and processed by the olfactory receptors located in the upper part of the nasal cavity, not by the nasal valve (Option D) Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra 8th Edition Page: 155, 156

questions.question: Match the following in relation to the internal anatomy of the nose. a. Anterior 1. Nasal septum b. Lateral 2. Choanae c. Medial 3. Vestibule d. Posterior 4. Lateral wall of nose
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a-3, b-4,c-1, d-2 Explanation: The boundaries of internal nose anatomy are shown below in the table: The nasal septum divides the internal nose into right and left nasal cavities. Each nasal cavity communicates with the exterior through the naris or nostril and with the nasopharynx through a posterior nasal aperture or the choana. Each nasal cavity consists of a skin-lined portion—the vestibule and a mucosa-lined portion, the nasal cavity proper. Anterior Vestibule Posterior Choanae Roof Roof of the nose separates the nasal cavity from the anterior cranial fossa Floor The floor of the nose separates the nasal cavity from the oral cavity Medial Septum: separates the right side of the nose from the left side Lateral The lateral wall of the nose Fig: Anatomy of Internal Nose Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra 8th Edition Page:155
